Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in New Zealand
Award.AbstractNarration:
-----

This action funds Johanna M. Nevitt of Stanford University to conduct a research project in the Geosciences area during the summer of 2013 at the University of Otago in Dunedin, New Zealand. The project title is "Improving Numerical Models of Fault Deformation at the Crustal Scale." The host scientist is Dr. Virginia G. Toy.

Numerical models of fault-related deformation are built upon a number of physical equations, including constitutive equations that define how rock deforms in response to stress. Implementing accurate constitutive equations is essential to producing significant and reliable model results. Rocks located within fault-zones may creep (i.e., deform viscously) in either a grain size sensitive (GSS) or grain size insensitive (GSI) manner, which is believed to result in either aseismic (steady-state) slip or seismic (earthquake-producing) slip on faults, respectively. Constitutive equations for GSS and GSI creep are currently poorly constrained, which limits our ability to model fault-related deformation, particularly at the crustal scale. This project determines appropriate constants for GSS and GSI creep constitutive equations by analyzing samples collected by scientific drilling into New Zealand?s Alpine Fault Zone. Microchemical and microstructural maps, created using energy-dispersive x-ray spectroscopy (EDX) and electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) analysis of the samples, reveal whether deformation occurred via GSS or GSI creep. The maps can then be imported into Elle, a modeling platform for simulating the two-dimensional evolution of microstructures in a polycrystalline material during and following deformation. Numerical experiments are conducted in Elle to determine the constants for the creep constitutive equations that best simulate the fabrics observed in the samples. Dr. Toy will eventually use these parameterized constitutive equations in crustal scale numerical models of the earthquake cycle on the Alpine Fault.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Upon returning to the U.S., the fellow will share what she learned with current and future users of Stanford's EBSD lab by creating a quartz-specific EBSD manual and leading a seminar on strategies specific to analyzing and modeling quartz deformation. This will be valuable, since no faculty members at Stanford are currently using EBSD analysis or numerical methods to study quartz deformation. In addition, the fellow will share her experience studying the Alpine Fault in New Zealand through "Geokids," a Stanford University outreach program that teaches basic earth science to elementary school children. In a more formal sense, the results of this project will be disseminated at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting in San Francisco in December 2013, and will be published in a peer-reviewed journal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In order to better understand the seismic hazard of a region, earth scientists build and analyze numerical models of fault-related deformation, notably earthquakes. Such models require the user to input equations and parameters that accurately describe how rocks accumulate deformation when stressed. The equations that relate stress to deformation are known as the “constitutive laws.” Because earthquakes in continental crust nucleate at ~10-15 km deep, it is particularly important to constrain accurate constitutive laws for rocks deforming under conditions representative of the mid-crust (10-15 km deep). Unfortunately, it is difficult to attain these conditions (pressure, temperature, stress state, strain rate) in a rock mechanics laboratory. As a result, our understanding of constitutive laws for deformation in the mid-crust is limited. The long-term objective of this research project is to examine microstructures in rocks collected at depth from the Alpine Fault Zone and use numerical models to establish representative constitutive laws for fault-related deformation in the mid-crust.

Microstructures (deformation textures at the micron scale) commonly are used to infer the nature of deformation within fault zones. We identified and analyzed microstructures in representative samples for two distinct rock types found in the Alpine Fault Zone. The Alpine Fault, located in the South Island of New Zealand, marks the Australian-Pacific tectonic plate boundary and is similar in scale and character to California’s San Andreas Fault. An important tool in our microstructural analysis was electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD), a cutting-edge technology in the earth sciences, which determines the three-dimensional orientation of mineral crystal lattices. Rocks deformed by crystal plastic deformation are expected to produce a crystallographic preferred orientation (CPO), which reveals the active intracrystalline slip system(s) and has implications for the conditions of deformation. EBSD and energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy (EDS) were used to create micron-scale microsctructural and microchemical maps for the Alpine Fault Zone samples. Surprisingly, both samples exhibited very weak CPOs, suggesting that crystal plasticity was not the primary mode of deformation. Instead, it appears that grain boundary sliding (GBS) and diffusion creep likely were the causative deformation mechanisms. GBS increasingly is being recognized as an important deformation mechanism in the lower crust and mantle and is thought to be a key component to plate tectonics.

Elle is an open source modeling platform for simulating the development of microstructures during deformation. At the start of this project, Elle was equipped for simulating an impressive number of microstructural processes, but unfortunately GBS was not one of them. We therefore needed to develop two new algorithms in Elle’s base code to build a functional GBS process. With GBS as part of its repertoire, Elle can now be used to investigate the effect of GBS on the constitutive behavior of fault-related deformation. In addition, GBS can be combined with other deformation mechanisms (e.g., diffusion creep) and tested on microstructural maps of real samples. Then, the relationship between stress and deformation can be recorded during the course of a numerical experiment. We are therefore one step closer to determining realistic constitutive laws for fault-related deformation in the mid-crust.

The code we developed during this project will be incorporated into the Elle modeling platform and freely available to Elle users around the world.
